description:
This is a reincarnation of TCG "Duel Masters" with some minor changes in rules.
Each player has a deck full of creatures and spells. The goal of the game is to finish an opponent with one of your creature's attacks. However, each player is protected by 5 shields, represented by face-down cards from a player's own deck. When your creature attacks an opponent (and is not blocked by another creature) it breaks one of his shields, and the shield card goes to the owner's hand.  When your creature attacks a defenseless opponent, you win the game.

The game has some similarities with the grandfather of collectible card games - Magic: the Gathering, which is also made by Wizards of the Coast. However, it has two major differences:
1. There is no distinct card class for producing mana. The same cards, representing creatures and spells, can produce mana if placed in the Mana Zone instead of the Battle Zone. This removes what many see as a major flaw of Magic: the Gathering - "mana flood" and "mana screw".
2. There are no instant spells or activated abilities. Therefore, there are far fewer surprises for players from their opponents and also fewer tactical decisions during play. On the other hand, it plays quicker and can be easier for children to learn and understand. Even so, it has strong strategic aspects and fun deck building.

Operation Peace for Galilee

Lebanon ‘82 is a simulation of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in ‘82, an attempt to clear out PLO terrorists and expel elements of the Syrian army from the country. Hoping to establish the pro-Israeli Christians as the legitimate government in Lebanon, the Israelis sent in the IDF, which soon became embroiled in vicious urban battles. The game also includes a 1975 scenario, as well as a 2006 scenario, showing the evolution of Israel’s ongoing struggle against the PLO.

Lebanon ‘82 utilizes the Fire & Movement combat system that is designed so that players can augment their units with “Support Fire” during the course of the battle. From artillery to air strikes, units can receive support assets to engage enemy positions and formations, allowing combat to develop at all levels. Lebanon ‘82 also includes rules for a possible Syrian entry, and features the Syrian Surface to Air Missiles! Israeli air support could come under fire from Syrian fixed SAM batteries; more support fire will be necessary, but assets are limited.

In Lebanon ‘82, the attritional design of the Combat Results Table simulates the true nature of modern warfare; Units are typically two-sided formations that can incur casualties during a game, accurately replicating the realities of combat, especially during the street fighting encountered in 1982. Winning the battle is thus a matter of maneuver, firepower and asset management — not merely odds ratios requiring numerical superiority. A stunning map of Lebanon depicts the entire battle area, ranging from the Israeli border to the capital Beirut itself — including all of the famous battle sites, such as the PLO refugee camps.

This is a strategy game for 2-8 racers.  The game aims to tell the "story" of Le Mans in 4 sets of races (rounds).  There are 246 cards that tell the store of the race and allow the players to move their cars along the track.  Each racer also has an endurance and various penalties can show up that will reduce their endurance.

You collect cards on your turn (6 cards max in your hand) and try to collect 3-5 cards from the same family; this will give you a bonus in your move or give you additional endurance to last longer.

You can also play on teams, with drivers on the same team, taking a team counter.

Rules are in both French and English.

The games was published in conjunction with the Automobile Club de l'Ouest (ACO).

Ukraine 1941 shows the very first days of Fall Barbarossa - a German attack on Soviet Union. 
Even though the Red army seemed very powerful its front line was almost annihilated during the first days of the campaign. But Stalin did also had tremendous reserves heading on the front...

This is the second game of K-2 system presenting southern front of German assault through steppes of Ukraine towards Kiev. Soviets seem to be hampered at first but as games progresses the problems for Germans arise.

Game allows to play first month of Fall Barbarossa in Southern part of Soviet Union. Map covers Eastern Poland, middle and Western Ukrainian territory and provide German, Romanian, Hungarian, Slovakian and Soviet forces that were involved in the region. Both Players must control as much strategic cities as they can at the end of the game.

There are 2 scenarios in the game: German initial assault on June 22nd and full battle which started when Romanian forces joined on July 1st.

A car racing game through Finland for 2 to 6 players. Players start the race from Helsinki and must visit Rovaniemi, before heading back to Helsinki.

Each player chooses a route order card he must obey, when driving from control point to another control point. The game includes also chance cards for unexpected events that may slow down or advance his race. When a player gets back to Helsinki, he must drive additional acceleration and brake test before the race is over for him.

A player with least penalty points is a winner of the Suomi-Rally.

In The Cave, a board game from K2 author Adam KaÅ‚uÅ¼a, players take on the role of a speleologist team tasked with exploring a newly discovered cave. Players start from a base and explore a cave, tunnel after tunnel, effectively building the board (the cave). They have to overcome steep descents, underground lakes, and tight squeezes. They will be given a chance to admire the wonders of the underground, like halls full of stalactites. To make it all possible they must take the right supplies with them, like ropes, oxygen and batteries.

Each turn players have five action points to use for moving, discovering new cave tiles, exploring them, and packing their backpacks when they go back to the starting base. They need ropes for descents, oxygen to explore underwater parts, and a camera to photograph underground wonders. Planning what to take with them is one of the most important things in the game. Each turn that their pawn is not in the starting base, players must use (i.e., throw out) one basic supply from their backpack; these costs, along with the expenditure of other supplies during exploration, forces them to return to the starting base a few times during the game. To keep them from having to carry everything, though, players can raise a camp somewhere in the tunnels where they can store some of the equipment.

The cave differs every game, so players have to be prepared for everything or they will lose time. Players earn points for exploring different tiles: underwater, wondrous, descents, and so on – but to win they'll need to acquire bonus prizes for exploring the most tiles of each type. This make decision-making during trips very difficult.

When the cave is fully explored, the player who made the biggest effort in the most spectacular way wins the game.

Objective: gain most horse cards
 - acting simultaneously -
all horse cards are placed in the middle of the table - uncovered. Each player gets a playing board with images of these horses.
Active player flips a card: first player who shouts 'Stop' gets the card; wrong? an already gained card must be discarded.
Game ends after all cards are caught.

Munchkin Pathfinder, which includes 168 cards and uses the setting of the Pathfinder role-playing game from Paizo Publishing, can be played as a standalone game or combined with any other core Munchkin game. That said, while Munchkin Pathfinder includes Classes and something new for this set – Factions – the game does not use Races.

As for what you'll find in the set, you can try out new classes like Alchemist and Witch; join a faction to become an Eagle Knight or a Red Mantis Assassin; or arm yourself with the T-Bone Stake and the Armor of Insults. You'll need those latter items to defeat the Ghoul Friday, the Whispering Tyrant, and especially Lamashtu, the Mother of Monsters. But first you'll have to fight your way through all those goblins...and kill them and take their stuff!

Munchkin Pathfinder Deluxe contains the same cards, die and rules as Munchkin Pathfinder, but also includes a game board, pawns and plastic stands. Munchkin Pathfinder Deluxe also features a brand-new mechanism — "Factions" — and a new D6 for the iconic Pathfinder Goblin.

From the company website:

DYSTOPIAN LEGIONS is a fast-paced, action-packed 28mm scale tabletop game set in the exciting world of Dystopian Wars, where Victorian super science fiction has created a fascinating and brutal arena for a deadly world war. The game is scalable from a small number of models right the way up to a full blown company of men with armoured support. A modular approach to army building guarantees the game embraces further new releases and game expansions.

Mennonite Manners is a simple fun and crazy dice party game. All you need is a sheet of paper per player, one pencil, and one six sided die. The first player to write out the numbers 1-100 wins.

Place the pencil in the middle of the playing area. Players each roll the die in turn until someone rolls a six. That player takes the pencil and starts writing out the numbers 1-100 as fast as they can. The other players continue rolling the die in turn. When someone else gets a six they gently grab the pencil from the player currently writing and start writing 1-100 on their sheet. Continue until someone gets to 100. Numbers may be checked for legibility.

The game doesn't sound like much, but usually generates a lot of laughter, especially when someone is just beginning to write and the pencil is grabbed away. If grabbing pencils sounds dangerous then you can try ringing a bell to stop play in order for the writing player to give the pencil.

Card game made as a promotion by the biscuit people, McVitie's.

The game has 34 cards: 15 sets of 2 cards each and 4 Joker Cards. Each set of 2 cards represents one "It's a Knock Out" game. It's a Knockout was a hugely successful TV show that featured people representing a  were invited to play very silly games. See the illustration where a man must ring a bell but he has to climb a greased slope to get to the bell. This would be a very typical It's a Knockout game.

The cards must be well shuffled and the complete pack dealt between the players. If some players get more than others, this does not matter in the normal course of the game. Every player looks at his cards and tries to find groups whose words and pictures fit together. Two fitting cards will be called a game, and the player who has one can lay it down when it is his turn to play. (If a player retains a 'game' in his hand he runs the risk of having the cards taken by his opponents.)

Each player holds his cards in his hand in such a way that the picture side cannot be seen by the other players. A nominated player starts and draws one card from his neighbour. If with this card he can form a game he can lay it down. Then his right neighbour draws one of his cards, and so on anti-clockwise. The first player to complete all his games shouts ’Knockout’ and places all his cards on the table.

The players then total up the number of points scored by each competitor on the basis of 5 points for each completed game, with the exception of the 'marathon' game (denoted by letter M) which qualifies for 10 points.

The Joker can be used at any stage of the game to complete the other half of a two card 'game', but this particular game only qualifies for standard points, i.e.5 If the Joker card is laid on top of a matching 2 card game this entitles the player to double points for the one 'game', i.e.10 points. The player with the highest number of points is declared the winner.

Goal Chance is a simple, quick-result soccer replay/simulation game which allows you to complete entire seasons very quickly and accurately with goal scorers and times of goals.  Gameplay consists of rolling the dice and referring to the player/team statistics on the team set cards and the game charts to determine which team won the match.

Goal Chance can be used with the expansion team sets from the following of Terry Goodchild's other soccer games:
Full Time, Soccer Replay or Final Score

although it is a much faster and simpler than those games, mostly used to get quick match results.

It comes with a rulebook and some charts.  Two 6-sided and 1 10-sided dice are also needed to play.

It can be purchased alone or with Full Time.

A soccer replay/simulation/management game in which dice rolls and charts are used to simulate the management and gameplay results of soccer teams.

Paraphrased from the Owzat site:

Team Squad Ratings, attack and defence are used separately, reflecting the squad strengths of the teams. These are constructed on a goals scored and conceded basis using the final league table to ensure an accurate statistical base. Individual team ratings are used for Injuries and Suspensions, for Injuries reflecting the effect of an injury to a key player of players on the Squad strength of the team, thus ensuring that the teams with smaller and less flexible squads will suffer more severely from injury absentees, for Suspensions penalising those teams that have proved over the season that they are rarely able to field a full strength side because of this reason (e.g. Arsenal, Leeds). Cash is allocated to each club, allowing the rich to enter the transfer market more freely than their less wealthy rivals, provided the right player comes along of course. Transfers in and out, injuries and suspensions are dealt with in a fairly abstract way, as is necessary in a game that is about teams and not individuals. Opportunities will arise to strengthen the Attack/ Defensive Squad Values, players may have to be sold which have the reverse affect, all without names but all having an immediate effect on team strengths and performances.

A day's fixtures, whether it be just a couple of mid-week matches or a full Saturday/Sunday programme, are valued as a complete package before any match is resolved. This involves checking for Injuries and Suspensions on a team-by-team basis and then assessing which Goal Card to use for each time by deducting one team's Defence Squad value from the opponent's Attack Squad value and rounding the result down to a figure divisible by ten. When all matches have been valued, a roll of two pairs of coloured dice per match will produce a half time score line, a second roll for each will give the full time result. Book keeping consists of marking up the result on the Results Matrix and up dating both the Cumulative Points and Goals For and Against Charts.

Wild Patterns  - A game of fast perception

Wild Patterns  is a family board game offering a mixture of fast perception, problem solving, and tactics.

The aim is to find patterns shown on your cards from the different colored wooden tiles constantly moving around the game board. The trickier the pattern, the more points they give. Constant changes within patterns cause sudden and surprisingly tricky situations.

You better be fast, because patterns can be scored at any time, even during other players' turn.

Keep focused, wild patterns are on the move!

Game duration is less than half an hour. The Game can be played by 2-6 players from ages 8 and up. Rules are simple and quick to comprehend.
Wild Patterns can be played as a short & easy or a long & tricky version.

---

Villit Kuviot  - nopean hahmottamisen peli

Villit Kuviot on nopeaa hahmottamista, ongelmanratkaisua ja taktiikkaa yhdistävä hauska koko perheen lautapeli. Yhden pelin kesto on noin puoli tuntia ja peli sopii sekä lapsille, että aikuisille. Pelin säännöt ovat helpot ja pelin oppii välittömästi.

Pelissä yritetään laudalla olevia värillisiä puukuutioita liikuttelemalla muodostaa kädessä oleviin kortteihin merkittyjä kuvioita. Pelin voittaa pelaaja, joka saa valmiiksi eniten korttien mukaisia kuvioita.

Pelissä pelilaattojen muutokset aiheuttavat hauskoja ja yllättäviä tilanteita. Pisteitä voi jopa tehdä vastustajien pelivuorojen aikana. Nopea visuaalinen hahmottaminen on tärkeää. Peli sopii kaikenlaisille pelaajille iästä riippumatta.

Pelaaja voi valita oman pelitaktiikkansa. Rakentamalla pieniä helppoja kuvioita saa vähemmän pisteitä, mutta enemmän kuvioita valmiiksi. Rakentamalla vaikeampia isoja kuvioita, pelaaja saa enemmän pisteitä, mutta ottaa riskin, että kuviota ei saakaan valmiiksi.

Nuoremmat lapset voivat pelata peliä ilman vaikeimpia kuvioita, kun taas haastetta kaipaavat voivat jättää pelistä helpot kuviot pois. Kun kokemus kertyy voi mukaan ottaa vaikeimmat erikoiskuviokortit, jotka antavat lisähaastetta.

Objective: Gain as many cards (=witches' brew) as possible
 - acting by turns -
flip top 'brew' card:
active player chooses one of the ingredients (sticks) out of the witches' vessel; if it matches you may draw another (if needed); wrong? Place stick(s) back into the vessel, next players turn.
If you finished a brew: keep the card. 
Drawing a spell? Turn the vessel at 180° 
Game ends after all cards are gone.

Fanny is a nice and helpful instructor. She tells you all about riding and horse care, how you have to hold the reins, and how you scrape the horse's hoof etc.
 Players choose their horse and starts racing. In his turn player rolls the dice and draws a card collecting various stuff he needs. If he must jump over the hurdles he needs horseshoes etc. or continues his ride until he collects things he needs

Who finish the race first is the winner.

Great fun for two little racers.

Player rolls the color dice in his turn and it shows the color of the next space player may advance with his car.
Who finishes first is the winner.

Players are on a trek around the world, trying to take photographs of the things they see, but somehow all the vowels are missing!  Complete the words by finding the missing vowels and you will move ahead on the Game Board.

Each player receives three Word Cards, and places them face up in front of them.  On your turn, draw a Vowel Tile and check whether it can be added to any of your own Word Cards.  If not, check whether it can be added to another player's Word Cards.  If it can, and it has no prior vowels added to it, you may exchange one of your empty cards for theirs and play your Vowels Tile.

If a player completes a word, they move ahead on the Game Board as many spaces as the length of that word (3 letter words move 3 spaces, etc).  The player must spell the word aloud for everyone to hear as they move their pawn on the board, then discard their used Word Cards and Vowel Tiles, and draw a new card.

The first time any player crosses either of the wooden bridges, recycle all the used Vowel Tiles from the Discard Tray back into the draw area, and rearrange them.  The first player to reach the Finish space wins!

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN:  The Vowels, Using Vowels to Spell, Word/Picture Recognition

Lastly, but by no means least, comes the gritty art of daring special operations. Small teams of highly trained troops going man-to-man against the best your enemy can throw at you. Capture a bunker, rescue hostages, eliminate a target or destroy a shield generator - this is what your elite troops trained for. We call this SPECIAL OPS and it will be presented using 28mm scale miniatures.

Source: Publisher blurb

Special Ops is third, and final tabletop wargame in Firestorm Invasion family. It uses dice and 28mm to recreate small scale special operations during final phase of planet invasion in Firestorm Armada universe.

Each player control small force made from 28mm miniatures and tries to fulfil scenario objective or smash his opponent.

Childrens card game. There are eight full sets of different Teddy cards. A set consists of five cards, a full-size Teddy and four other cards, each a quarter of the related Teddy.

Deal 7 cards to each player. The first player must play a full size Teddy card if he has one. If he doesn't, he draws a card. Once a full size Teddy card is on the table, the next player can play either another full size Teddy card or can add a quarter card to any matching Teddy currently on the table. You must play a card if you can but you may only ever play one card per turn.

When a set is finished, the player playing the last quarter card on it, scores 1 point. The first player to use all their cards scores 5 points. The winner is the first player to score 11 points.

Pentanque on the table.

There are discs instead of balls and players throw them as close as possible to jack. Player (or team) who has his ball closer to jack is the winner.

Bacchanalia is a narrative game for 3-6 people. Following the rules, each player creates a fictional character – a person accused (justly or not) of a crime against the empire and on the run with her lover. The game starts when the protagonists find themselves passing through Bertinoro, a settlement on the hills of Romagna by the Via Aemilia and close to the Ravenna port.

Unfortunately for them, in that torrid summer, Bacchus and his followers came down to this village surrounded by vineyards. Attracted by the excesses brought forth by intoxication, other gods manifest themselves; cruel Pluto, severe Minerva and the sensuous Venus will play with the destiny of mortals with all the thoughtlessness only gods can have. The player's objective is to reunite with her beloved and run away. Each player in turn draws a hand of cards and, based on the results of the draw, describes a scene from the story for her protagonists. Elements of the scene vary according to which god was more present in the draw. For instance, a scene dominated by Pluto will feature a violent crime in which the protagonist ends up somehow involved. Benevolent Venus reunites lovers. Bacchus brings thrill and excitement, and so on. There is a clear winning condition – reuniting with the beloved and running away before your accuser catches you – but one player reaching it doesn't prevent other players from doing the same; multiple winners are possible.

In the chaos of the bacchanal, will the fugitives be able to reunite with their beloved and get to safety? Or will they meet a harsher end? Will they be caught by their accuser – or will they be lost forever in the rapture of the bacchanal?

From the packaging:

"An addictive game of strategy versus risk for any number of players. Roll the dice and build your score... but learn to judge when to stop!"

The game comes in a plastic blister pack. It contains a "velveteen" dice pouch, six dice with roman numerals, a black-and-white rule book with historical notes, and a black-and-white score pad.

A turn consists of the player rolling all six dice. If he scores any points, according to a list of scoring combinations (e.g. three "D"s score 500 points), he may then set aside these and roll again, getting the chance to accumulate more points. Alternatively, he can stop rolling and keep his accumulated score. If he rolls a no-scoring throw, then he  scores zero for that turn, even if he had set aside scoring dice from previous rolls. His points are then recorded, and play passes on to the next player. The game ends when someone scores 5000 points; everyone else "with a turn left" then gets a chance to better this player's score.

The historical notes claim that this is a real ancient Roman game, originating from the late republic.

As of writing, this game is being sold in museum shops in the UK, at historic sites related to ancient Rome (e.g. sites on Hadrian's Wall).

Children's picture dominoes game but with a real twist - with sound! Besides the 28 domino cards, you have Marvin the Electronic Mouse.

There are seven types of images, Ship, Bicycle, Motorbike, Tractor, Car, Train and Aeroplane. Marvin has sound effects to go with each image.

Each player gets a number of dominoes depending on the number of players. These are laid out in front of you picture-side up. One domino is also placed in the centre of the table. Marvin must be in easy reach of all the players.

In your turn you must press Marvin's button and he will play a sound (example - ring-a-ding). Now, everyone looks at their dominoes at the same time, looking for a bicycle domino that will fit to the array of dominoes in the centre (of course, normal domino rules apply). If you have a domino that will fit at either end of the array, you must quickly press the blue button on Marvin. Play continues until someone uses all their dominoes and that person is the winner.

Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game is set in the Marvel Comics universe. To set up the game, players choose a mastermind villain (Magneto, Loki, Dr. Doom, Red Skull in the base game), stack that particular villain's attack cards underneath it, then modify the villain deck as needed based on that villain's particular scheme. Players then choose a number of hero decks – Spider-Man, Hulk, Wolverine, etc. – and shuffle them together; since players use only a handful of hero decks out of the fifteen included, the hero deck can vary widely in terms of what's available.

Over the course of the game, players will recruit powerful hero cards to add to their deck in order to build a stronger and more resourceful deck. Players need to build both their recruitment powers (to enlist more heroes) and their fighting ability (to combat the villains who keep popping up to cause trouble). Players recruit heroes from an array of five cards, with empty slots refilled as needed. At the start of a player's turn, he reveals a villain and adds it to the row of villains. This row has a limited number of spaces, and if it fills up, the earliest villain to arrive escapes, possibly punishing the heroes in some way. Some villains also take an action when showing up for the first time, such as kidnapping an innocent bystander. The villain deck also contains "master strike" cards, and whenever one of these shows up, the mastermind villain (controlled by the game) takes a bonus action.

As players fight and defeat villains, they collect those cards, which will be worth points at game's end. Players can also fight the mastermind; if a player has enough fighting power, he claims one of the attack cards beneath the mastermind, which has a particular effect on the game. If all of these cards are claimed, the game ends and players tally their points to see who wins. If the mastermind completes his scheme, however – having a certain number of villains escape, for example, or imposing a certain number of wounds on the heroes – then the players all lose.

Hero decks in the base game: Gambit, Black Widow, Hawkeye, Emma Frost, Thor, Spider-Man, Iron Man, Storm, Captain America, Nick Fury, Rogue, Cyclops, Hulk, Wolverine, Deadpool

UNRELEASED GAME

    
    
         This game is scheduled to be released at Spiel 2013 

    


Note that all details for this game are preliminary. 

In an apartment building, the tenants are having a laundry day.  Their task is simple: to hang clothes on the balconies.  But, the air and shaky hands might cause some of the clothespins, pinza de ropa in Spanish, to fall, or mysteriously end up on a higher floor of the building!

The players alternate turns during which they try to have as many clothespins as possible on their floor.  Each player's floor is designated by a secret objective card (marked with a star).

During their turn players choose a floor on the board, roll the dice, and then may play cards to affect the outcome of the dice.  Each number on the dice different from the player's floor means that a clothespin must go to another floor.  A special objective card indicates which floor is best for that player's clothespins.  The winner of the game is the one that gathers the most points, based on the special objective card and a player's played cards during the duration of the game.

The print & play version which will be available through this site and the publisher's page is the family version of the game.  A future version of Pinza de Ropa will include a new advanced version, with more cards, strategies, and surprises that will make the game even better!

The only thing not provided in the print'n play version of the game are the 5 dice.  You will need 5 6-sided dice to play.  Also, if you wish, you may use real clothespins.  We have provided a .pdf with a printable clothespin, but if you want to pimp out the game...

There are 48 cards with various pictures.
Shuffle the cards and distribute them to the players.
In his turn player draws the top card, look at it and says what his aunt carries for her journey.
e.g. if the card shows mattress player says: "My aunt is on a trip and carries the mattress"
The next player draws the top card from his deck and says same sentence as last player and adds the detail from his card, so that the list of things the aunt carries goes longer and longer.
Player who make a mistake is eliminated from the game.
The last player left is the winner.

Dierenvrienden (Animal Friends)

Encouragement and experimenting is what matters. Your child's selfconfidence will grow while playing together. By answering questions about animals, drawing animals or mimicing animal behaviour correctly players score points and progress on a scoringpath. In the end one of the participants will reach the finish first and can claim victory.

With questions in 3 categories, children learn a lot about the animals around them and build beautiful animals themselves.

This is not a standard game as winning is not the goal, but the game-play progresses until one person passes the end of the scoring track first.


Dierenvrienden is geen standaard bordspel: in dit bordspel draait het namelijk niet om winnen, maar om proberen. Het aanmoedigen van uw kind en de ontwikkeling staan centraal. U zult zien dat het zelfvertrouwen van uw kind door Dierenvrienden spelenderwijs zal groeien.
Door vragen te beantwoorden over dieren, dieren te tekenen of dieren na te doen worden punten verzameld. Diegene die als eerste het eindpunt bereikt mag zichzelf de winnaar noemen.

Kinderen krijgen vragen in 3 categorieën, leren zo alles over het dierenrijk en maken zelf de mooiste dieren.

There are 16 memory tiles and 15 slide-tiles in this game.
In start shuffle tiles separately and lay slide-tiles on the table. Then draw a top memory tile and roll the dice. Dice shows how many times You may swap the slide-tiles to find the picture of the memory tile. If You are successful You get the card as a point You may continue Your turn.

If memory-tile deck is exhausted the game is over and the player with the most cards wins.

In this memory variant, players must find 3 cards that form the combination (f.e: Pirate, Pirate Ship, Treasure)
In his turn player turns around 3 tiles and if he finds a trio, he takes the tiles and continues his turn.
Game ends if all tiles are taken.
The player with the most trios is the winner.

Objective: Move from your East Frisian island up to the mainland collecting 5 ingredients (preparing tea)
and get back again
 - acting by turns -
each player gets an island, the 'Alte Fritz' - a neutral figure - is placed in Aurich. 
active player rolls the die - you need a 'joker' stepping from island to mainland; successful?
move vertical or horizontal if possible into cities, but do not step upon 'Alter Fritz', because he'll send you to the jail (smuggler). Get these ingredients during your stay;  outside you can be challenged by other players (rock, paper, scissors) to win/loose an ingredient or you may make a deal findind the one you were searching for.
Moving back to your island you must roll a 'joker'. 
remarks:
Production: Ravensburger Freizeit- und Promotion

"Humans thought they were alone in the universe.
                                            They were right!"

Timestreams takes place in a possible future, where the human race has made two very intriguing discoveries: 1) We are alone in our universe.  2) There are universes in which other races exist and function in a totally different time frame than ours. The problem is that now that we know, the other races know as well. Thus, the beginning of the timestreams invasion is now taking place, during which entire races invade the parallel timestreams.  These invasions cause temporal distortions, causing a dimensional vortex that may cause one race or more to be so distorted that it will be impossible to interact with anything from a three dimensional universe.

Timestreams is a game where players alternate turns and try to wreak havoc for their opponents. All players start with their player card next to a timestream, and during the game they try to avoid being in the same timestream with another players.

Sometimes, a player must calculate a temporal distortion, and all players that are on the same timestream as another must lose an amount of this distortion by counting on their vortex resonator. The winner is the last race standing, after everyone else's race has reached its critical point.  There is no player elimination.  Players will continue to play until the end of the game and take their vengeance on the opponents that took them out.

Duel of Ages II is a time-scramble board game played between two opposing sides each having 1 to 4 players, with uneven size allowable. Each side controls a selected team of 8-12 characters from different ages of time: Ancient, Colonial, Modern and Future. The goal is to win greater glory in overcoming adventures and in tactical combat than the opposing team.

Although multiple styles of play are available, the standard DoA game-play involves seven phases:


     Selection of each side’s team of 8-12 characters (kept secret).
     Building of the interlocking puzzle map to best suit your character’s skills.
     Selection of a Team White and a Team Black based on character Respect.
     Revealing and equipping of characters.
     Bringing characters onto the map based on Respect.
     A sequence of game rounds where characters maneuver on the map to accomplish adventures, hunt enemy characters and avoid dangerous situations. 
     Counting of total achievements won. The team with the most achievements wins.


The game can end at a certain time or after a certain number of rounds.

Game play is an unusual mix of tactical wargame-style combat, treasure gathering, and non-combat character teamwork and adventuring, and has no close comparison to other games. Differences between characters are significant, with many having poor fighting skills. Game play and winning is therefore an act of balancing fighting, treasure-gathering and adventuring.

From the game box:

Select a team of characters. Overcome adventures and the enemy team to win favor, achievements, and ultimate victory. And while you are at it, enjoy the stories that your game builds.

Errata (Changes to cards):

An Enemy Turned (Lith Card, Secret): Remove the second paragraph. Enemies cannot be switched if they are imprisoned.

Prince Wallard Blatt (Character): Wallard is killed permanently if he takes damage from anything not caused by a successful Hit. For example, damage from Cube effects or trade damage caused by Hakan. For this purpose, poison damage is caused by a successful Hit.

Chancellorsville: Bloody May, 1863 is a two-player wargame simulating Jackson’s infamous flank attack that occurred west of the Chancellor House (Chancellorsville) on May 2, 1863. As the Confederate player, you must try to crush Hooker’s unsuspecting army. As the Union player, you must regroup from the initial shock of the blow, hold onto the Chancellor House, and counter-attack against Lee’s outnumbered forces.

Following the debacle at Fredericksburg in December of 1862, President Lincoln replaced Burnside as commander of the Army of the Potomac with Maj. Gen. Joseph Hooker. Hooker came up with one of the most audacious flanking maneuvers of the war. Leaving two corps at Fredericksburg to pin Lee, he would march the rest of his army north and west, cross the Rapidan River, and place himself at Chancellorsville. The move, if successful, would place the Army of Northern Virginia between two Union armies, ready to be crushed as if in a vise. The opening move worked, but then Hooker sat still as if waiting (or daring) for Lee to attack him. Lee did indeed attack. But the move was so unconventional as to catch Hooker completely by surprise. Lee divided his forces in the face of the enemy—a textbook no-no—not once, but twice! First, he left a group at Fredericksburg to delay any Union crossing in that area. Then, with his remaining forces, he left only two divisions in front of Hooker, while the remainder of his army under Jackson (28,000 strong) marched around the Union right and attacked them in the rear at sunset on May 2, 1863.

CBM is an old-fashioned beer and pretzels game that is not burdened with cumbersome command & control or supply rules.

Paul Koenig's Bloody Civil War Series is based upon the intermediate system of Avalon Hill's Gettysburg 1977.

The game consists of 50 mystery cards. They contain an illustration and a short statement about a spooky or crime event. On the back of the card, the story is presented in more detail. Only one of the players reads the back of the card. The others try to reconstruct how the crime happened by asking yes/no questions.

Translated from the manual

Tiro Finale is a card game based on Mami's and the Cake Witch's battle in Puella Magi Madoka Magica

The game consists of 2 types of cards, Mami cards representing Mami's power and Witch cards representing the Cake Witch. All cards have a power of 1 to 6.

The game is about being the first to claim that the total of Mami's power (both the open information on the table and the hidden information in each player's hand) is bigger than that of the Witch.

Translated from the manual

All players have spent six depressing years in junior high and high school. The only somewhat colourful memories from those years are the memories together with their childhood friend and the class' top student, Shizuka Miyamoto.

On the graduation day, Shizuka left with the words "I'd liked to have really fallen in love with someone", and a couple of months later, the players are devastated as they hear she has married some guy her parents introduced.

Soon thereafter, the players see an advert recruiting people wanting to participate in a "time-space jump experiment. Only for people with strong minds."

The players participate in the experiment, and use the time machine to try to improve their past. The time machine is powered by strength of mind. The unhappier past, the stronger mind, so at the start, players are able to go back all six years. But as they change the past and get happier, their mind weakens.

Who of the players will be able to catch the heart of Shizuka Miyamoto?

User summary

Players represent teams of cats trying to get ahold of the treats being delivered. Treat cards are lined up, with numbers on them, showing which cat(s), in queue order, will get the treat. Players play cat cards with different numbers of cats on them, face down, onto the treat cards. Once all cat cards have been played, the cat cards for each treat are turned face up and points are dealt to the player(s) who have "their" cat in the right position. "Cat Kick" cards will kick away the cat card in front of them.

A half quick game of bluffing and guessing.

(English "block man") Swedish children's game. Wooden blocks lay face down on the table. In a Memory like fashion players take turns finding the right blocks to build a complete figure. Starting with shoes, then legs and so forth. Several leg or torso pieces can be stacked creating a funny looking final figure.

Supposed to train memory and hand/eye coordination

The cards are evenly distributed. Each child puts his cards face down in front of him. Now, in turn, clockwise, the top card of the pile is turned face-down. As soon as two matching cards are on the table: who calls the first flip, wins the pile of his opponent. But beware cards not indetical may look same at first sight.
Last player in game is the winner.

Shuffle the deck and each player places his cards face down on a pile. The player with the shortest name begins and open his top card. Then the next player open his top card etc.
Different things may happen by opening cards:
1) Someone turns a card already opened by any opponent.
Player who calls "Flip" first gets both card and places them bottom of his deck.
If "Flip" is called wrongly, the penalty is discarding one of his card to flip-pot deck.
2) Card shows dice. Player rolls it and the dice shows action to player must do:
Change the direction, take the flip-pot, take all open cards from table, exchange Your discard pile with chosen opponent's discard pile etc.

Game lasts to pre-agreed time-limit. Winner is the player with the most cards.

FreshBiz is a game that fundamentally changes the way its participants play their business and life by simulating and then practicing new, creative methods of entrepreneurial thinking, and problem solving to achieve their most vital goals.

Through its game-based learning, participants travel through the game on a mission to win, while gaining skills, understandings and strategies that not only help them to achieve the goals in the game, but also to excel in their lives.

Utilizing common business practices, and years of insight from entrepreneurs, FreshBiz uses tools such as the buying & selling of businesses, leveraging, negotiations, loans, business opportunities and more to simulate a business environment. Simultaneously, relationships are being forged and the atmosphere of the room buzzes as participants engage with themselves and others in entrepreneurial, multi-dimensional thinking.

Insights gained during a 60 to 90-minute game last far into the future, as our participants claim that the game impacts them for the rest of their lives. There is a distinction between change and transformation. Working harder, doing something less, spending more time else, etc are change, while transformation through FreshBiz is what shifts your paradigm completely and offers you the opportunity to play business, relationships, and life in a whole new way.

As you play FreshBiz, your goal is to reach the "Winner" lot in 90 minutes. In order to achieve your objective, as you pass from section to section (paying tolls to pass), you will have to handle different business dimensions and practice entrepreneurial skills.

The Businesses
In order to pay tolls as you cross through the board on the way to the Island, you will need to earn money. One of the many ways to do that is by starting businesses. Each player gets different businesses cards and each business card has an establishment cost and a profit. You will have to be creative and smart in handling your budget, cash flow, and strategy in order to turn your original capital into the profits you need to move ahead in the game.

Action Cards

Just as in life, each player starts the game with their own unique set of Action Cards. Essentially, these are your gifts, talents and special abilities in the game. It's up to you to use them in the best way possible, and they can be played during any turn. So, be creative and you will make money and friends The Stock Market, Loans, & Partnerships As you go through the game, there will be many business dimensions that you can leverage to help you win, such as the Stock Market, Loans, Partnerships and more...
The more dimensions you master the better results you will get and the more fun you will have...in FreshBiz and in life! So go win!

The road ahead beckons, and you want to run the course from start to finish as quickly as possible before you run out of gas. But looking ahead, some of those curves are a little steep. Perhaps it is best not to drive too fast.

Each turn you play one card from your hand, adjust your speed accordingly, and move over the appropriate number of road sections. Taking a curve too fast or a jump too slow results in damage which is paid by discarding player cards. If you cross the finish line card, you win. If you run out of cards or are unable to take enough damage, you lose.

Created for the 2012 Solitaire Print and Play Contest

Wacky family word bowling game that features a unique wooden character dice ball that determines the amount and location of bowling pin tiles to flip over in attempt to spell words in each bowling frame to score big points. The ball comes in endless color combinations and features letter, numbers and symbols to challenge players word skills.

Player roll the dice, open indicated number of ball-tiles in indicated locations and try to form a word to score points.
After multiple rounds player adds up their points and the player with the most points is the winner.

The Wild Vikings have been looting once again and return to the Viking village with their treasures. But horror of horrors! Nessie, the lake monster, suddenly appears in front of them and their ships gets into trouble sea. Will the Vikings manage to arrive at the village where the are safe and where they can divide up their precious loot?

Wild Vikings the card game is a simple bidding game with one round of bidding. A die dictates the turn of a player, either Nessie eats a ship, a bidding round starts with him, he gets the viking token, the player with the viking token draws a card or everybody draws a card.

There are 3 kinds of ships and 3 kinds of equipment cards to bid on the ships. Equipment cards can also be jokers for either color. Ships have values between 1 and 5.
The player who gains the most treasure wins the game.

Play as your favorite Kaiju from the popular Godzilla franchise in this classic style board game of dice rolling.

Roll the die and move your Kaiju around the game board fighting the other player's Kaiju. Use special abilities on your Kaiju's game card to perform range or melee attacks when in battles or defensive attacks against Kaiju.

Game objective; defeat the other player's Kaiju to win. Each player (in a standard game; 2 players) picks 4 Kaiju to play as. In a 3+ player game, players only choose 3 Kaiju.

Game features 12 Kaiju from Godzilla series;
-Anguirus
-Burning Godzilla
-King Ghidorah
-Godzilla
-Little Godzilla
-Mecha-Gigan
-Mecha-Godzilla
-Mothra
-Gigan
-Zilla
-Mothra Larva
-Rodan

In essence a roll/spin and move game, advertised in the 1950s as "fun for all the family".

Game board, 2 dice, 4 pawns and 4 sets of coloured counters.

No image of the board is available but it is apparently a board with an outside track and an inner grid of "Roo" squares. According to the rules the object of the game is to monopolise as many 'Roo blocks' as possible by forming more 3-counter rows - horizontally, vertically or diagonally - than opponents. 10 points are scored each time a row of 3 is formed. A player rolls the dice to move around the track, and the track block on which he lands indicates the Roo block on which he is allowed to place one of his counters. When a particular Roo block means there is no chance for a player to start a row of 3 or block an opponent that block is considered dead and from then on no player moves to it. When all Roo blocks have been played out players compute their scores and highest score wins.

Publication details from The Game Catalog: US Games Through 1950, 8th edition, 1998. Rules from gamearchives.org.

Tactical level wargame based on Japanese robotech animation "Aura  Battler Dunbine". This game is one of the First Step series games for beginner.

Each unit represent one aura machine, include aura ship and aura battleship.

The turn sequence is simple, Repeat of movement and simultaneous attacking. The rule is only five pages, but some important elements is included. For example the aura power requirement level or difference of fire combat and close combat.

Victory condition is stated for each scenario.

Swedish quiz game. (english: "Finally, commercials!"

The questions are linked to different tv commercials, municipality slogans etc.

The game is played by one player drawing a card and reading the question. If the players on the other team(s) answer correctly they get to keep the card. The game ends when the draw pile runs out of cards.

Swedish quiz game. (English: "sport geek").

Simple quiz game with failry uncommon sports questions.

The game is played by one player drawing a card and reading the question. If the players on the other team(s) answer correctly they get to keep the card. The game ends when the draw pile runs out of cards.
